metadata.name: Vanishing Horizons #34
metadata.description:
"I never wanted color to be color. I never wanted texture to be texture, or images to become shapes. I wanted them all to fuse together into a living spirit." - Clyfford Still


I have spent most of my life residing in urban environments. While figurative art is not a style I typically pursue in my own work, I delight in discovering abstract elements within it. The cities I've inhabited have consistently offered me the chance to do so through their architectural landscapes.

Le Corbusier once said that a metropolis's abstract skyline serves as its autobiography, etched in steel and glass, unveiling its history, character, and ambitions. In this series, my aim has been to encapsulate that sentiment using a minimalistic canvas and a monochromatic palette. Abstract expressionism remains my lens for viewing every artwork. 

The style of this series is my homage to Clyfford Still, an abex artist I have always admired. His ability to convey profound meaning through seemingly empty and unfilled canvases has always intrigued me. 

Implemented in JS, this code utilizes the Perlin.js and Simple-noise.js libraries.

Press s to save the image in full screen. 

Pixel Love!

metadata.name: Bindu #55
metadata.description:
The series employs fractal circles to create repeating patterns, using a monochrome color palette on the canvas. The number, size, and density of circles as well as the level of recursion, vary across pieces. The introduction of these variations and arcs adds a new dimension to fractals by juxtaposing their self-similar nature at all scales with elements of randomness.

This is my third series in a row that features a monochromatic color palette. There's something about the limitation of using only binary colors that enables me to appreciate abstraction purely for its form.

Note on the name: The series draws its name from Sayed Haider Raza of the Bombay Progressive Artists' Group. I have always admired Raza‚Äôs use of sacred geometry and his abstract work has forever been a source of inspiration. Raza believed that ‚ÄòBindu‚Äô (the dot, point or circle) is the ultimate point of creation, representing the universe in its entirety.

Implemented in JS, this code utilizes the Perlin.js and Simple-noise.js libraries.

Press p to save a png of the image in full screen. Press s to save an svg file.

Pixel Love!

metadata.name: Classic Automaton #83
metadata.description:
This is classical Automaton for those who loves "automaton" [cellular automata algorithm] as it is. Black and white  representation of standard algorithm organized in "Classic Automaton" canvas based on selected rules and is "framed" in Automaton variation of rules in same time.

The basic proportion of result artwork is related to square, 2 squares and 0.5 squares as a tribute to the system of "double square" proportion scale.

- "Tap" or "Mouse Click" on screen to rebuild variation;
- Press "s" key on the keyboard to save generated result in maximum resolution possible 4096 or 8192 px depends on iteration`s proportion of the result canvas to lossless PNG image file.

*use the browser`s functionality to zoom and pan the canvas.

metadata.name: contrapuntos #179
metadata.description:
Musical counterpoint is to me an abstraction of the layered, intertwining rhythms of every activity we carry on in our lives. With a global tempo typically set in days, we fit all sorts of temporal structures where our joys and fears live and play out over the span of our lives. This series is a metaphorical transposition of the musical counterpoint into a visual space, sometimes with repeating patterns, sometimes with broken structures, sometimes isolated notes / hours / souls.

Artwork by Marcelo Soria-Rodr√≠guez, @msoriaro. Made with p5js & glsl.

metadata.name: Absorbed #307
metadata.description:
A collaboration between leading British high-end audio brand KEF, generative artist hieroglyphica, and creative studio Parameta, Absorbed embodies the process of noise becoming high-fidelity sound through KEF‚Äôs Metamaterial Absorption Technology (MAT‚Ñ¢). 

MAT‚Ñ¢ makes the KEF sound what it is: absorbing unwanted distortion to deliver pure, accurate sound exactly as the artist intended. Inspired by this intricacy, Absorbed illustrates pseudorandom networks of patterns, slowly emerging and transforming into the maze-like form of MAT‚Ñ¢. Clarity is revealed, noise is absorbed ‚Äì high-fidelity is found.

The noise fields used in Absorbed are of two distinct types: conventional gradient noise and ‚Äúsinusoidal‚Äù noise, an original algorithm developed for this series. The use of animation as artistic medium reflects the artists‚Äô belief that no single frame can capture the full range of complexity found in the tension between sound and noise, and lets collectors observe for themselves this ever-shifting dialogue. A more extensive discussion of the algorithms used in Absorbed can be found in hieroglyphica‚Äôs companion article on fx(text).

- spacebar will pause and resume the animation
- s will save a still image of the current frame
- technically minded collectors can consult the index.html file for info on how to render and save high-resolution images
- use of hardware acceleration in Chrome may impact performance

Founded by BBC engineer Raymond Cooke in 1961, KEF is a leading British innovator of high-end audio products including HiFi speakers, subwoofers, architectural speakers, wireless speaker-systems, and headphones. Find out more at kef.com or visit our Discord at discord.com/invite/u48Z9yjY2q.

metadata.name: All That Could Be #160
metadata.description:
This token was created for THE PASSAGE: Pitch Drop experience, an interactive minting experience where your choices determine the artist and design of your token. 

To take part, please purchase an Edition 5 Coin on fx(hash) by HERE & NOW.

The artwork and experience draw inspiration from the 'The Pitch Drop Experiment': the world's longest-running laboratory experiment. Since 1927, only nine drops of pitch have fallen, and it has never been witnessed live.

All That Could Be is about the inner life of pitch drops waiting for their inevitable fall.

After first learning of the pitch drop experiment and understanding what this odd hyper-viscous liquid was‚Ä¶ all I could think about was: How does the pitch feel about all of this? What does it dream of? How does it deal with this intense pressure to snap, drip and perform?

All That Could Be acts as a metaphysical microscope into the emotional state of the pitch. The anticipated explosion of energy and pain when it loses its battle with gravity‚Ä¶ as well as daydreams imagined to brighten its dark, slow existence with vibrant, static-y layers‚Ä¶ or fantasies of being anywhere else besides trapped in a funnel under a locked encasement for the entertainment/curiosity of others who just hope to see you snap into two.

For more info:
https://hereandnow.events/

Procure a coin to participate in the event:
https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/slug/here-and-now:-edition-5

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Some key commands in live mode:

G : Toggle grain
A : Toggle aura
S : Save current resolution
1 : 3000x3750
2 : 4500x5625
3 : 6000x7500
4 : 7500x9375
5 : 9000x11250
6 : 10500x13125
(1-6 work best on Chrome/Edge)
(rendering takes longer as resolution increases)

metadata.name: glory hole$ #318
metadata.description:
our consciousness as humans can be distilled into a crudely fashioned hole at an abandoned dave & busters and the meditative state that is endured while sitting on a neglected toilet praying for the sound of disrupted waters. glory holes embody anonymity and pleasure for pleasure's sake. they are creations that cannot be destroyed, as they exist in the memories of anyone who uses or witnesses. many speculate that the carving of the hole is the purest form of human ingenuity and the desire to explore the unknown. formerly limited to the physical space. these glory holes transcend space and time. and exist in that same unknown that tempts us all. legalize ground beef. create nothing. consume everything.

HUGE thank you to @PureSpider for the layered PNG template, this dream would not have been realized without you friend.

attributes.value: come for the games stay for the cure

metadata.name: The Emoji Finder Game üîé #121
metadata.description:
This is a 'Where's Waldo'-like video game(!) that procedurally generates one of seven fun and hectic "biomes" to search through. Find the specified emoji before time runs out to win! 

The seven biomes are: Safari, Ocean, Space, Kitchen, Twitter, Forest, and City. Share your game links with friends! 

Created by Michael Perusse | https://twitter.com/mrperusse

metadata.name: Klyft #961
metadata.description:
‚ÄúKlyft‚Äù is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at PARIS+ par Art Basel.

Klyft is a juxtaposition of two different projections for the future. One, made by the World Economic Forum, suggests that the global gender gap will have closed by the year 2154. The other, by the UN IPCC, estimates that global warming will reach 3.2 degrees celcius by the year 2100.

Klyft makes use of the unique temporal aspect of computational art by developing its expression gradually over the next 132 years. As we come closer to 2154, the space between the two shapes in Klyft will grow smaller to symbolize the closing of the gender gap. As time goes on, however, Klyft also becomes more and more glitched out to represent the projected increases in greenhouse gases and climate catastrophes.

In the end, Klyft‚Äôs expression will be heavily corrupted, and the two shapes will have reached each other.

¬∑ URL parameters ¬∑

You can add the following parameters to the URL to change the behavior of the piece.

date=<YYYY-MM-DD> ‚Äî See how Klyft looks on another day. Use the format YYYY-MM-DD. 

color=<number> ‚Äî See the piece in another color scheme. The numbers loop around, so 17 equals 0, 18 equals 1, etc. 

resolution=<number> ‚Äî View the piece in a higher resolution. 1 is normal resolution, 2 is double, etc. No decimals allowed.

image=true ‚Äî Save the piece as an image. 

record=true ‚Äî Save the piece as a video in WEBM format.

Adding the following URL parameters will show Klyft in double resolution on the day gender equality is achieved according to the WEF:

date=2154-01-01&resolution=2

Adding the following URL parameters will save a video of Klyft in the ‚ÄòStokkendahl Dalgas‚Äô color scheme:

color=14&record=true

¬∑ Interactions ¬∑

Pressing the following keys will trigger functionality as well as add related URL parameters automatically. 

Pressing D will increment the date by 1 year.

Pressing C will increment the color index by 1.

Pressing R will toggle between normal and double resolution.

Pressing I will toggle the image URL parameter, which saves the piece as an image. Only works outside of iframe.

Pressing V will toggle the video URL parameter, which saves the piece as a video. Only works outside of iframe.

There are secret key presses as well. Some of them only work outside of iframe. 

¬∑ Accessibility ¬∑

Klyft is built to support screen readers. It has been tested using MacOS‚Äô VoiceOver, and uses p5.js‚Äô describeElement() to provide screen reader functionality.

If you have any comments (good or bad) on the screen reader integration, don‚Äôt hesitate to reach out on my Twitter: @ada_ada_ada_art. 

¬∑ Credits and license ¬∑

Klyft is made with p5.js.

Klyft is licensed under a modified version of the Climate Strike License (CSL).

metadata.name: CENTURY-XXX-METALOEWENSBERG #110
metadata.description:
CENTURY-XXX-METALOEWENSBERG is an homage to Ohne Titel (1969‚Äì1970) by Verena Loewensberg.

2 of 5 in CENTURY-XXX, Series 2
Edition of 128

CENTURY-XXX is a series of software sketches that pay tribute to artists of the 20th century. Each piece is named after a specific artist and reimagines one of their original works through code, often by adding motion, variation, or interactive elements. These sketches don‚Äôt replicate the original artworks but instead extend their core ideas into new forms.

By ‚Äúsoftware sketch,‚Äù I mean something more informal than a finished artwork. While some of my projects take months or even years to complete, these sketches are created quickly‚Äîoften in just a few days. They may be lighter in process, but they‚Äôre equally important to me. Sketching with code is how I think through ideas and discover new directions for future work.

The project began with the CENTURY exhibition at DAM Projects in Berlin in fall 2012, where I premiered Network C, Network D, and the first Signal to Noise software piece. Since then, these sketches have inspired more full-scale artworks like METASOTO, METAVASARELY, METAMOLNAR (also known as Hommage √† Molnar), including the eponymous CENTURY released through Art Blocks in June 2021.

CENTURY-XXX Series 1 was released from December 2021 to January 2022 in editions of 1,000. The first artwork in Series 2 followed in October 2022, also in an edition of 1,000. The remaining four works in Series 2 are scheduled for release starting in 2025, each in smaller editions of fewer than 128 based on what feels appropriate for the individual piece.

The long-term vision for CENTURY-XXX is to create 100 software sketches, each one inspired by a different artist and artwork from the 20th century.

SERIES 1
1.1 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METAMETAMALEVICH
1.2 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METAMOLNAR(S)
1.3 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METAMORELLET
1.4 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METARILEY
1.5 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METAKELLY

SERIES 2
2.1 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METAFRANKE
2.2 ‚Äî CENTURY-XXX-METALOEWENSBERG

More CENTURY-XXX‚Äôs to come‚Ä¶

metadata.name: Swedish Forest #42
metadata.description:
If I had to choose a place where time was frozen and where I could contemplate the landscape for eternity this place would be a scandinavian forest.
I have been contemplating these kind of landscape for a very long time both in Sweden and in the Pyrenees where the ecosystem is very similar.
This project generates an illustration of a scandinavian forest in many different situations. At day and at night, in every season of the year, next to a lake or not, with steep hills or at the plains, snowing, with preponderance of some plant species over others, etc.
The artwork is also drawn in various paint modes and layouts.

The sun or the moon may be visible, the moon shows always the actual moon phase based on the current date.
The reflection on the lake is the fxhash morse endcoded.


Developed in vanilla js using svg and canvas
Rendering can be unresponsive on slow devices
Click or touch to switch to Parallax mode, just move the mouse or finger.


[S] Download in SVG format
[D] Download in PNG format

Features:

Layout: Landscape, Portrait, Square
PredominantSpecies: Blueberry, Lingonberry, Calluna, Rocks, None
Trees: Mixed, PinesAndFirs, Birches, None
Season: Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter
DayNight: Day, Night
PaintStyle: Normal, Stroke, Paint, WhiteOnBlack, BlackOnWhite
ColorStyle: Normal, Crazy
HasLake: True, False
HasTrees: None, Few, Many, Crowded

Created by Daniel Juli√† Lundgren, fxhash: danieljulia.tez, twitter: @daniel_julia. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: Dreamcatcher Forest #665
metadata.description:
"Dreamcatcher Forest" is part of the fxhash interactive minting experience at Art Basel, Basel 2022. The illustration in this work draws inspiration from Native American dreamcatchers, a protective talisman crafted from beautifully intricate patterns of woven thread, built from natural materials & colorful beads.

Dreamcatchers are used to protect dreamers while they sleep. Good dreams are able to slip through the web to meet the sleeper beneath, while bad dreams are trapped and prevented.

- Use the "S" key to save a PNG image.
- Use the "P" key to export a print-quality image.

metadata.description:
Structures in construction.

Press 's' in full screen mode to save a 1280x2024 version.
Press 'h' in full screen mode to save a 2560x4096 version.
